Dear Ms. Taylor:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
September 17, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Barbara A Cote, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1)An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all of
the following information prior to employment or at the
time specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance
within 30 days of the completion of the probationary
period or within 180 days, whichever is less, and a
written evaluation of the employee's performance
annually thereafter.
2

Five of fifteen total employee files reviewed were either lacking an employee’s
performance review or did not have the performance review completed within 180
days.
CCI Rule 400.4147 Dental care
(2) A dental examination within 12 months prior to
admission shall be documented or there shall be an
examination not later than 90 calendar days following
admission.
One of three youth files reviewed had a completed dental examination more than
90 calendar days from admission.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and
date an initial treatment plan for each resident within 30
calendar days of admission.
One of three youth files reviewed had an intial treatment plan completed more
than 30 days from admission. The treatment plan was one day late.
CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and
date an updated treatment plan for each resident at least
once every 90-calendar days following the initial
treatment plan.
One of three youth files reviewed had two updated treatment plans completed
more than 90 days following the initial treatment plan. Both updated treatment
plans were completed one day late.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care,
all of the following information shall be documented in
the case record within 14 days after discharge:
(f) The name and official title of the person to whom the
resident was discharged.
One of three closed youth files reviewed, failed to include the name and offical title
of the person to whom the youth was discharged.
3

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The agency was provided the Michigan Adult Tuberculosis Risk Assessment Tool
form to identify if current employees need TB testing since their last TB test.
• The agency was informed they cannot use handcuffs or leg shackles when
transporting youth to a secure setting. The facility was asked to update and send
their Behavior Support and Management Policy.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. The agency currently has four pending investigations with two of the
investigations being investigated collabroatively with DCWL and Child Protective
Services (2024SIC0001725 & 2024SIC0001814).
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
2023 Renewal: Corrective Action Plan was recorded during this reporting period as
a result of the Renewal inspection completed on 08/15/2023. This CAP contained
rule violations of CCI Rule 400.4166 where the facility failed to document
appropriate information on discharge plans. The CAP contained action items of
using a checklist to make sure all information is included in a discharge summary.
Special Investigation 2023C0000721SI with CAP approval date of 10/26/2023 was
a result of a violation for failure to follow up on a youth’s grievance. The facility
hired a new recipient restraint trainer and trained staff. The facility is currently
complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor CAP
compliance with no noted concerns.
Financial Overview
4

The Agency’s annual third-party audit report for fiscal year ending December 31,
2023, was reviewed by the Bureau of Audit. The audit report included financial
concerns. Special investigation 2024SIC0001631 reviewed the financial concerns
and determined no licensing violations. The facilities financial condition will
continue to be monitored in subsequent audits.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was submitted and reviewed. Chief
Administrator reported until recently things have been going very well at the facility.
Within the last 30-45 days there has been a struggle at the facility due to veteran
staff helping at another facility (same organization) leaving Vassar House without
seasoned, veteran staff. Chief Administrator reported the facility recognized this
issue, brought back the veteran staff and are working to empower staff and offer
more trainings. Four new staff were recently hired and are completing training.
When a youth is referred to the facility the Chief Administrator is going to where the
youth is located and meeting the youth face to face as well as taking to the
caretakers/providers.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported they feel supported by leadership and have the tools to do their job.
Staff recognized there have been recent struggles but feel they are back on track
with the youth and have clear expectations from leadership. Staff stated the youth
are provided with regular counseling, outings, clothes and their needs are being
met.
Youth interviews were conducted during the audit inspection. Youth reported
feeling safe, having their needs met, and like the outings. One youth stated she
would rather be home but "this place is ok." Youth talked about off campus
outings, events they do at the facility and feel staff do their best to keep them busy.
One youth described youth getting into verbal altercations but staff stepping in to
redirect and separate youth when necessary.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An onsite inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on September 17,
2024. There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
5

Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
